Andy Coulson has decided to resign as my director of communications, although I understand that the continuing pressures on him and his family mean that he feels compelled to do so," David Cameron said in an e-mailed statement. Andy Coulson has told me that the focus on him was impeding his ability to do his job and was starting to prove a distraction for the government. -- Editors: Eddie Buckle, Anthony Aarons. When specifically asked on Radio 4's Today programme whether Andy Coulson had offered to resign over the continuing News of the World phone-hacking controversy, David Cameron said: I don't have to go into private conversations. He admitted that Andy Coulson was embarrassed by the speculation. But David Cameron gave him a big vote of confidence by stating that he judged people on whether they were doing a good job in a fair and decent way

Bernie Sanders said in his letter that the nation's political climate had been damaged by a "right-wing media echo chamber" that is transmitting a reactionary world view to the tens of millions of millions of Americans who watch or listen to them every day. In a separate statement, state Republican Chairman Steve Larrabee said: "By using this tragedy to demonize those he disagrees with, the Barack Obama is doing exactly what he pretends to deplore."
